title: Nutrition and Aging
content: The conversation focuses on nutrition as it relates to aging and longevity. The discussion is centered around the literature on caloric restriction, epigenetic clocks, aging and its effect on DNA and cell reprogramming. The focus then shifts to protein and aging. Protein is the one macronutrient that stands out, as carbohydrates and fats are really there for energy use, protein is not. The importance of muscle mass, the RDA on protein itself, IGF, growth hormone, and a lot more are discussed.

title: Challenges with Understanding the Effects of Nutrition and Studying Interventions for Aging
content: The relationship between nutrition and longevity is complex. The biology of aging and the biology of nutrition are both complicated, making it difficult to draw definitive conclusions. There are many things we don’t understand yet about optimal nutrition and how that intersects with optimal health span. The benefits of a drug are still trying to be pieced together, imagine putting this together for the topic of food/ nutrition. The environment also plays a big role in these studies.

title: How Convictions on Nutrition and Thoughts Optimal Health Have Evolved
content: Convictions on nutrition have become looser as time goes on. Fewer and fewer things are viewed with certainty. Clinically, nutrition is viewed from a very simple 2×2 framework. It’s important to sort people into a bucket to answer the questions‒ Do you need an energy deficit? Do you need an energy surplus? What’s your protein intake need to be to achieve that in combination with your calorie needs? It’s also important to be willing to change our beliefs about nutrition and other aspects of health as more data comes in.

title: Finding Optimal Health, Actionable Steps, in Face of Confusing Science
content: If you can be somewhere close to optimal nutritional intake (just say total calories and body composition is somewhere close to where it should be), that’s a big chunk of what you need to give yourself the best chance of being healthy going forward. You don’t have to optimize every single thing. Starting from that big picture perspective allows you to get most people most of the way there. And then when they’re most of the way there you can focus on how do we get that last 10, 20, 30%, whatever it is.

title: Calorie Restriction for Improving Lifespan in Animal Models
content: From the animal literature, caloric restriction seems to reproducibly improve lifespan. The first experiments were published in the early-mid 1930s. Findings of early studies of restricting calories during early life/ development of rats show‒ smaller body size, lifespan increases by 40-50%! (living their whole lives in the laboratory). Rats also seem to be healthier as they live longer.

title: Utility of Epigenetic Clocks and Possibility of Epigenetic Reprogramming
content: People in the field are really enamored with aging clocks, epigenetic clocks, and biochemical markers. These are useful, but more so would be showing that the heart is still functioning like a young heart or the immune system in an elderly individual is still functioning like it does in a young individual. There are lots of type of clocks. When most people use this term today, they mean an epigenetic clock. This relies on changes in epigenetic marks, changes in the genome that occur with age. In every organism where it has been studied, characteristic changes are seen in the epigenome with age. This can provide a good chronological measure of aging.

title: Epigenetic Clocks and Biological Aging
content: Epigenetic clocks might have value in determining the biological age of an individual. The proof of this is being able to predict an individual's biological age at some point in their life and with some precision, predict what’s going to happen in the future. Longitudinal studies in people have taken samples 10, 20, 30 years ago and measured epigenetic profiles then ask, “How well does that correlate with mortality outcomes in the future?”

title: Epigenetic Changes and Aging
content: Epigenetic changes are 1 of 8-10 molecular processes that seem to contribute to aging. The idea that reversing the epigenome is reversing aging is at best an exaggeration, at worst an outright lie. Epigenetic changes, the methyl groups that sit directly on cysteine residues in the DNA do primarily, is affect expression of the genes. What you’re seeing with aging, we think, is a shift in the epigenome that leads to certain genes being expressed that shouldn’t be and certain genes not being expressed that should be.

title: Epigenetic Reprogramming and Aging
content: Epigenetic reprogramming factors can extend the lifespan dramatically, maybe 50%. These are impressive changes that are consistent with the idea that you fixed or made something better. The idea is to go back far enough that you restore the epigenome to its pristine state, young state, and then hope that when you do that, you restore gene expression to where it’s supposed to be. Potential benefits of epigenetic reprogramming include restoring the homeostatic mechanisms to a more youthful state where then the homeostatic mechanisms that all of our cells have can basically clean up the rest of the mess.

title: Inflammation and Aging
content: Inflammation is a huge driver of our loss of ability to recover as we get older. All sorts of things go wrong if you have a high level of sterile inflammation in your body, including the ability of stem cells to function. A lot of injuries require stem cells to function, to build back what’s been broken.

title: Mutations and Aging
content: We know mutations accumulate as we age. That’s what drives a lot of cancer. We have known this for a long time. The epigenetic changes are on top of this. The question is, do mutations happen with enough frequency to be a major contributor to functional declines that go along with aging. Mutations certainly contribute to cancer.

title: Potential Downsides of Epigenetic Reprogramming
content: The question is: Will epigenetic reprogramming work in every tissue/organ? We don’t really know. Maybe we will see really large effects on lifespan and healthspan in mice. How do you do that in the brain? Because so much of who we are and what we are comes from our experiences and our memories. How do you ensure that you can reprogram somebody’s brain in a way that isn’t going to change that?

title: Potential Downsides to Epigenetic Reprogramming
content: We don’t know the potential side effects of epigenetic reprogramming. Certain types of cancers are a side effect of this partial reprogramming in mice. There are reasons to be concerned that this is going to be hard to implement therapeutically. The FDA is going to be extremely skeptical of this kind of approach. People are going to need to show with really rock solid, compelling data that reprogramming strategies are not going to cause significant side effects. This may be a long road to get reprogramming strategies into the clinic.

title: First Potential Applications of Anti-Aging Therapies
content: An amazing application would be to target osteoarthritis. If you could figure out a way to regenerate human cartilage without joint replacements, those are huge wins that seem a little more feasible. A niche application is exactly the strategy people have tried to take with senolytics. These are molecules that will clear senescent cells. That path has been hard too.

title: Advice for Aging Well
content: You don’t have to do EVERYTHING right, get 80% of the way there. Nutritionally this is very challenging for some people, but most can do that. Exercise, you don’t have to optimize your physical activity, but do something. 50% of the benefit of exercise is captured from going from nothing to about 15 MET hours per week. The point is that you can get (depending on the study) 30-50% of the benefit (of exercise by) going from being completely sedentary to 15 MET hours per week.

title: Impact of Calorie Restriction on the Immune System, Muscle Mass, and Strength
content: The effect of caloric restriction (CR) on the immune system of laboratory animals is complicated and there are several confounding factors. Some studies on pathogen challenges on CR animals show they respond better than age-matched ad libitum fed control animals. However, sepsis experiments show that CR animals die much more quickly than controls. In the state of CR without optimal nutrition, that’s where you really worry about side effects, particularly immune deficits. Most functional measures of aging seem to be preserved in calorically restricted animals. This includes measures of frailty and sarcopenia.

title: Insights from Famous Calorie Restriction Studies in Rhesus Macaques
content: The caloric restriction study at the University of Wisconsin and the NIA (National Institute on Aging) showed different results. The Wisconsin animals (both controls and CR) were fed a very processed diet. The CR animals were fed 30% less than what the control animals were fed. In that experiment, they found a benefit to caloric restriction. The CR animals outlived the control animals and had fewer age-related diseases. The experiment in Bethesda may have not been deliberately different but the DIET was different. These animals were actually fed the closest diet that could mimic their real diet. The net result of the Bethesda study was there was no difference. The CR animals did not live longer.

title: Caloric Restriction and Aging
content: The impact of caloric restriction on aging is still unclear. Molecular signatures of caloric restriction have been studied in monkeys and rodents, with many shared changes in mTOR signaling, mitochondrial function, and other metabolic pathways. However, it is still uncertain whether these effects would be the same in humans. The Wisconsin experiment suggests that reducing the amount of unhealthy food you eat is beneficial, but it does not suggest that if you have a good diet, eating less will help you live longer. It is also unclear whether the Wisconsin animals lived longer simply because they lost weight or because they lost weight and were eating less processed food.

title: Evolutionary Perspective of the Human Diet
content: Humans have an incredible capacity to store excess energy, which is needed to support our brain. Metabolic sickness comes not with the inflation of subcutaneous fat but when it spills out into the viscera, liver, peripancreatic space, perinephric space, and pericardial space. The problem is fat that escapes the normal depot of subcutaneous fat is inflammatory and metabolically disturbing. Humans seem to be fairly robust towards eating really, really bad diets for many years before significant consequences are seen. This may be due to our metabolic flexibility.

title: Antiaging Diets: Fact vs Fiction
content: There are many popular dietary interventions that people claim have an effect on aging, including caloric restriction, intermittent fasting, time-restricted feeding, fasting-mimicking diets, ketogenic diets, and protein restriction. However, there are many more questions than answers when it comes to these diets and their effects on aging. For example, it is unclear whether the benefits of a ketogenic diet come from caloric restriction or from the diet itself. Similarly, it is unclear whether the benefits of protein restriction come from caloric restriction or from the diet itself.

title: Psychological and Biological Consequences of Diet
content: If the diet is not ad lib, there are psychological consequences to not eating when you want, to being hungry all the time. But those have biological consequences as well.

title: Mouse Models of Time-Restricted Feeding
content: There’s been a couple of papers in mice that make a compelling case that the lifespan benefit from, say a 30% caloric restriction diet, is a combination of WHEN the animals are eating and HOW MUCH they’re eating. Most of the benefit comes from the calories. For example, let’s say you get a 30% lifespan extension from 30% caloric restriction. ⅔ of that benefit comes from the calories. ⅓ of the benefit actually comes from the fact that those mice eat all their food in a short window and are fasted essentially the rest of that 24-hour period.

title: Impact of Time of Day for Feeding
content: An experiment to compare the impact of calories not time of day for feeding. This compares the impact of calories and there is only fasting when they sleep. At least 1 of the 2 studies Matt was referring to did this. Fasting drives the metabolic, molecular, and geroprotective effects of a calorie restricted diet in mice. Circadian alignment of early onset caloric restriction promotes longevity in male C57BL/6J mice. That’s how they were able to identify that ⅔ of the benefit came from the reduction in calories and ⅓ came from the additional fast.

title: Eating Early in the Day Versus Late in the Day
content: Most people would agree that if you’re eating something that causes your blood sugar to spike, doing that right before you go to bed is probably suboptimal. So if you’re going to do a time-restricted feeding, it might be better to eat earlier and not right before bedtime.

title: Studies of a Ketogenic Diet
content: There have really only been 2 studies that have looked at the lifespan and healthspan of mice on a ketogenic diet. One study of lifelong ketogenic diet saw no effect on lifespan. Another study used an intermittent ketogenic diet, something like every other day or maybe once every 3 days or something. On the other days they ate a regular diet. In some ways this was an intermittent caloric restriction. They found a 15% increase in lifespan.

title: Impact of Calorie Restriction When Started Later in Life
content: For a long time, the dogma was that caloric restriction didn’t work if you started it past, I don’t know, 15 months of age, which is maybe the mouse equivalent of a 40, 50 year old person. Most of the early caloric restriction studies were done starting sometime pre-development. Early rat studies were pre-development and 6 or 9 months of age. If you do a graded onset of caloric restriction, you can get lifespan benefits from caloric restriction at 20, 22 months of age.

title: Caloric Restriction and Lifespan
content: Those animals lived longer than mice that went on CR late in life. The difference in the maximum lifespan is trivial, the real differences between the groups is in the median lifespan. Questions arise such as: Is it about the total time you’ve been on CR? Is it an interaction with how old you are (the developmental process) when you do CR? What happens when you go on CR at the end of life, which is mostly the degenerative process?

title: Rapamycin and Lifespan Extension
content: With rapamycin, the data are pretty clear that you can start rapamycin well into middle age and maybe even into very old age, and get most of the benefit. If you compare the curve here where they started the mice on CR at 22 or 24 months, the effect is pretty small compared to CR. With rapamycin, you get almost exactly the same benefit, starting at 20, 22, 24 months as you do starting early in life.

title: Bioavailability of Rapamycin
content: Rapamycin gets broken down in the pH of the gut. So basically if they just put the powder in the food, there’s no bioavailability, it doesn’t get taken up by the mice. Matt has heard of several cases now where the bioavailability is much lower in the compounded rapamycin in a capsule than in the actual Rapamune.

title: Protein Intake and Aging
content: One of the other things that came out of Matt’s review article of the animal stuff was protein restriction. Of all the topics in nutrition, this is the one Peter is most interested in. Mouse studies show protein restriction can extend lifespan. There are different flavors of protein restriction and it’s not clear that the mechanisms are the same across these different flavors of protein restriction.

title: Impact of Protein Intake on mTOR
content: The common mechanism that does seem to potentially underlie all of these forms of protein restriction is inhibition of mTOR. Protein is an activator of mTOR and we know a fair amount about the biochemistry of that, that particularly branch chain amino acids can directly activate mTOR through sestrins. It seems intuitive that protein restriction would be beneficial by turning down mTOR.

title: FGF21 and Protein Restriction
content: FGF21 is the other important player in protein restriction (particularly total protein restriction). FGF21 is secreted in response to a low protein diet, and then has effects on liver metabolism. It also inhibits mTOR and reduces IGF-1. So that seems to be required for the lifespan extension that is seen from protein restriction in mice, potentially partially upstream of mTOR in liver metabolism.

title: Protein Restriction Studies in Mice
content: Branch chain amino acid and methionine restriction studies are pretty clear that those animals are consuming more calories than the ad libitum mice (certainly if you match to weight), and they’re living longer. We don’t know the mechanism by which methionine exerts this effect. Lots of mechanisms have been proposed: mTOR likely plays a role, Methionine is used to synthesize S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) which is a methyl donor for DNA methylation so maybe it’s important for epigenetic modifications, Methionine is the first amino acid in every protein, so there could be effects on protein synthesis, There’s evidence linking methionine restriction to sulfur amino acid biology, which has been implicated in aging.

title: Impact of Protein Intake on mTOR Activation
content: How long is mTOR activated in response to the increase in amino acids? It will depend on what you eat in combination with the protein, when you eat, and how active you are. Free amino acids are very short in their ability to turn on mTOR. It’s so short-acting that the idea of using BCAA analogs to treat sarcopenia was going to require drugs that could stay on much longer.

title: Inborn Diseases and Branched-Chain Amino Acids
content: There are some inborn diseases of childhood where you have elevated levels of branched-chain amino acids. There are consequences to even having somewhat modest increases in mTOR, say, hyperactivation of mTOR signaling chronically. The muscle protein synthesis window is open long enough that simply delivering a great source of whey protein in the hours after a workout seems sufficient to not restrict muscle potential growth.

title: mTOR Inhibition and Muscle Loss
content: People for a long time thought that rapamycin (an mTOR inhibitor) would cause muscle loss, but we don’t see that in mice or in people or in dogs. It is guessed that this has maybe more to do with WHERE mTOR is being affected, than HOW MUCH we’re inhibiting mTOR.

title: Low-Protein vs. High-Protein Diets
content: There was an interesting study where they looked at a range of diets with different composition of 3 macronutrients (carbohydrates, fats, and proteins) and asked, 'What does it look like in terms of metabolism, energy expenditure, lifespan?' Diets where the mice lived the longest were towards the low end in protein. An ad lib diet with 40% protein resulted in the best absolute lifespan (they were not calorie restricted at all).

title: Protein Intake and Muscle Mass
content: The question for people is, 'How important is dietary protein in that maintenance of muscle or loss of muscle (in people who are going the wrong direction)?' There are lots of studies that have compared the RDA to double the RDA standard. Protein makes a very big difference following the training that is necessary to stimulate muscle protein synthesis.

title: IGF-1 Signaling and Growth Hormone on Lifespan
content: IGF-1 is insulin-like growth factor one; it’s a hormone. You can think of it as a growth promoting hormone, part of this central pathway that promotes growth in many, many different tissues. If you have high growth hormone levels, you’ll have high IGF-1 levels and high mTOR. IGF-1 is a part of the mTOR pathway as well, upstream of mTOR.

title: Growth Hormone and Aging
content: There are several different mutations in this pathway, it’s complicated and there have been controversies about mutations that directly affect IGF-1 itself and the effects on lifespan. But there’s no question that mutations that reduce growth hormone signaling in mice extend lifespan. It’s important to understand that those studies are all cases where the animals are deficient in growth hormone through development‒ these animals are very, very small.

title: Growth Hormone and Health
content: There isn’t enough data to suggest that growth hormone is safe or unsafe. Growth hormone has been widely used in sports, potentially abused. Some side effects of growth hormone and anabolic steroids include increased blood pressure, increased blood sugar, and sleep disturbances. From mouse studies, growth hormone therapy could potentially increase the risk for various diseases, including cancer. However, some patients claim to feel better after taking growth hormone. The role of IGF-1 signaling in mortality is unclear and complicated.

title: High Protein Diet and Health
content: Epidemiological studies show mixed results on the impact of a high protein diet on health. Some studies suggest no downside to eating a high protein diet, while others suggest potential risks. A high protein diet may be beneficial for those over 50, especially if they are exercising. However, a high calorie, high protein diet could be problematic for those who are overweight, diabetic, and sedentary.

title: Low Growth Hormone Signaling and Health
content: People with mutations in the growth hormone pathway, resulting in low growth hormone signaling, do not show a difference in lifespan compared to those with normal growth hormone signaling. However, they do show a significant reduction in cancer risk. The reason for their unchanged lifespan could be due to higher rates of alcoholism, liver failure, and accidents.

title: Nutrition and Healthspan
content: The impact of diet and growth hormone signaling on healthspan and cancer risk is complex. Lifestyle factors, such as being overweight or sedentary, can influence the effects of a high protein diet. High growth hormone signaling may not necessarily lead to a higher risk of developing cancer. The immune system's ability to detect and clear cancers declines with age, which could contribute to the increased prevalence of cancer in older individuals. A healthy diet and regular exercise can contribute significantly to healthspan.
